UML

source: Tutorials Point

UML (Unified Modeling Language) is a standard language for specifying, visualizing, constructing, and documenting software systems.

UML - Overview

Goals of UML

  • To help the conceptualization of OOP development;
  • provides a general purpose modeling language;
  • UML is easy to understand for not just developers, but business users and common users. It descripes what is happening in the development of a project.

A conceptual model of UML

Consider a conceptual model as the following:

  • A conceptual model can be defined as a model which is made of concepts and their relationships;
  • such models are the step before UML diagrams, helping to understand entities and how they interact with one and other.

It is important to have a conceptual model of your project, before trying to work out all the details in a UML diagram. The conceptual model of UML can be mastered by the following three elements:

  • UML building blocks,
  • Rules to connect the building blocks,
  • Common mechanisms of UML.

Object-oriented concepts

In object-oriented processes, an object contains both data and methods that control the data, which represents the state of the object. A class describes an object and they also form a hierarchy* to represent the real-world system. The hierarchy follows a strict inheritance system.

UML is able to represent all concepts that exist in object-oriented analysis and design. Following are some fundamental concepts of the object-oriented world:

  • Objects →objects represent an entity and the basic building block;
  • Class →a class is the blueprint of an object;
  • Abstraction →represents the behaviour of a real-world entity;
  • Encapsulation →encapsulation is the mechanism of binding the data together and hiding them from outsider parties;
  • Inheritance →the mechanism of making new classes from existing ones;
  • Polymorphism →defines the mechanism to exist in different forms.

OO analysis and design

The most important purpose of OO analysis is to identify objects of a system to be designed.

An efficient analysis is only possible when we are able to start thinking in a way where objects can be identified, whereafter the objects and their relationships are identified and the design is produced.

The purpose of OO analysis and design can be described as:

  • Identifying the objects of a system;
  • identifying their relationships;
  • making a design to be converted to executables using OO languages.

The three basic steps where the OO concepts are applied and implemented:

OO analysis → OO design → OO implementation using OO languages

  • During OO analysis, the most important step is to identify objects and describe them correctly, providing clarity in later stages. Objects should be identified with responsibilities—the functions performed by an object. All responsibilities collaborated fulfills the purpose of the system.
  • During the second phase, OO Design, focus is on the requirements and their fulfillments. The objects collaborate according to their intended association, finishing the design.
  • The third phase, OO implementation, the design is implemented using OO languages such as Java, C++, etc.

Role of UML in OO Design

As a modeling language, UML is used to model (non-)software systems. The emphasised use of UML is with modeling OO software applications. Most of the UML diagrams discussed so far are used to model different aspects such as static, dynamic, etc. Now whatever be the aspect, the artifacts are nothing but objects.

It is important to understand the relation between OO design and UML; the OO design is transformed into UML diagrams according to requirement. The input from OO analysis and design is the input to UML diagrams.

UML - Building Blocks

The building blocks of UML consist of 3 main categories: Elements, Relationships, and Diagrams.

Elements

Elements are the most important building blocks of UML. They can be...

  • structural,
  • behavioral,
  • grouping,
  • annotational.

Structural elements

Structural elements define the static part of the model. They represent the physical and conceptual elements. They are:

  • class →represents a set of objects having similar responsibilities;
  • interface →defines a set of operations, which specify the responsibility of a class;
  • collaboration →defines an interaction between elements;
  • use case →represents a set of actions performed by a system for a specific goal;
  • components →describes the physical part of a system;
  • node →can be defined as a physiscal element that exists at run time.

Behavioral elements

Behavioral elements consists of the dynamic parts of an UML model. They are:

  • interaction →defined as a behaviour that consists of a group of messages exchanged between elements to accomplish a specific task;
  • state machine →is useful when the state of an object in its life cycle is important, defining the sequence of state an object goes through in response to events (external factors responsible for change).

Grouping elements

Grouping elements can be defined as a mechanism to group elements of a UML model together. There is only one grouping thing available:

  • package →gathers structural and behavioral elements.

Annotational elements

Annotational elements help to capture remarks, descriptions, and comments of UML model elements. It should be the only thing used to render comments, constrants, etc. of an UML elements.

Relationship

Relationship is one of the most important UML building blocks. It shows how elements are associated with each other, ultimately describing the functionality of an application. There are 4 types of relationships:

  • dependancy →a relationship between two elements in which change in one element also affects the other;
  • association →a set of links that connects the elements of a UML model. It also describes how many objects are taking part in that relationship.
  • generalization →can be defined as a relationship which connects a specialized element with a generalized element. It basically describes the inheritance relationship in the world of objects.
  • realizations →can be defined as a relationship in which two elements are connected. One element describies some responsibility, which is not implemented and the other one implements them.

UML diagrams

UML diagrams are the ultimate output: all element and relationships are used to make a complete UML diagram to represent a system.

UML includes the following 9 diagrams:

  • class diagrams,
  • object diagrams,
  • use case diagrams,
  • sequence diagrams,
  • collaboration diagrams,
  • activity diagrams,
  • statechart diagrams,
  • deployment diagrams,
  • component diagrams.

UML - Architecture

A real-world system will be used by many different users, each with different perspectives and goals in mind. It is important to visualize this difference in perspective, which helps to build a better system in the end.

The core perspectives are:

  • design →consists of classes, interfaces, and collaboration. They are UML class- and object diagrams.
  • implementation →defines the components assempled together to make a complete physical system. They are UML component diagrams.
  • process →defines the flow of the system.
  • deployment →represents the physical nodes of the system that forms the hardware. UML deployment diagrams is used to support this perspective.

In the center of these perspectives is the use case, which connects all 4 and represents the functionality of the system. Hence, other perspectives are connected with use cases.

UML - Modeling Types

It is very important to distinguish between the UML Models. Different diagrams are used for different types of UML modeling.

Structural modeling

Structural modeling captures the static features of a system. They consist of:

  • classes diagrams,
  • objects diagrams,
  • deployment diagrams,
  • package diagrams,
  • composite structure diagrams,
  • component diagrams.

Structural models represent the framework for the system and is where all components exist. Hence, the class diagram, component diagram, and deployment diagrams are part of structural modeling. They all represent the elements and mechanisms to assemble them.

The structural model does not describe the system's dynamic behaviour.

Behavioral modeing

Behavioral models describe the interaction in the system. It represents the interaction between the structural diagrams and they show the dynamic sequence of flow in a system. They consist of:

  • activity diagrams,
  • interaction diagrams,
  • use case diagrams.

Architectural modeling

Architectural models represent the overall framework of the system. It contains both structural and behavioral elements of the system. Architectural models can be defined as the blueprint of the entire system. It includes package diagrams.

UML - Basic Notation

UML notations are the most important element in modeling. Efficient and appropriate use is very important for making a complete and meaningful model.

Notations are a key part of understanding UML. UML diagrams are made using the notation of elements and relationships.

Each of the aforementioned UML building blocks has a specific notation.

Notation of structural elements

Graphical notations used in structural elements are most common in UML. These are considered as the nouns of UML models.

Class notation

UML class is divided into 4 parts:

1. name of class
2. attributes of class
3. operations performed by class
4. any additional components

Object notation

The object is usually a subitem of a class is represented the same way, with the only difference is that the name is underlined.

Interface notation

Interface is represented by a circle. It has as name which is generally written below.

Interface is used to describe the functionality without implementation. It is just a template where you define different functions, not implementations. When a class implements the interface, it also implements the functionality as per requirement.

Collaboration notation

Collaboration represents responsibilites. Generally, responsibilities are grouped.

They are represented by a dotted eclipse with a nmae on the inside.

Use case notation

Use case is used to capture high level functionality of a system.

They are represented by an eclipse with a name inside and may contain additional responsibilities.

Actor notation

An actor can be an external- or internal entity that interacts with the system.

Initial state notation

Defines the start of a process and found in nearly all diagrams.

Final state notation

Describes the end of a process, and used to show the termination point of a process.

Active class notation

Similar to a class, but with a solid border. Active class usually describes the concurrent behaviour of a system.

Component notation

A component in UML is used to represent part of a system for which UML diagrams are made.

Node notation

Represented by a square box with a name. It represents the physical components of the system, such as server, network, etc.

Notation of behavioral elements

One of the most important elements of UML are dynamic parts. Out of the powerful features UML has to represent the dynamic part of systems, 2 important features are interaction and state machines.

Interaction notation

There are 2 types of interactions:

  • sequential, represented by the sequence diagram;
  • collaborative, represented by the collaboration diagram.

Interaction notation is basically a message exchange between two UML components.

Interaction is used to represent the communication between the components of a system.

State machine notation

State machine describes the different states of a component in its life cycle.

It is used to describe different states of a system component. The state can be active, idle, or any other depending on context.

Grouping elements - package notation

Package notation is the only element in UML to group elements together. It is used to wrap the components of a system.

Annotating elements - note notation

Used to provide necessary information in a system.

Relationships

There are 4 types of relationships in UML:

  • dependancy,
  • association,
  • generalization,
  • extensibility.

Dependancy notation

Describes the dependant element and the direction of dependancy.

Association notation

Describes how elements in an UML diagram are associated, showing how many elements take part in an interaction.

Association is represented by a dotted line with (without) arrows on both sides. The two ends represent two associated elements as shown in the following figure. The multiplicity is also mentioned at the ends (1, *, etc.) to show how many objects are associated.

Generalization notation

Describes the inheritance relationship of the object-oriented world.

Extensibility notation

All languages (programming or modeling) have some mechanism to extend its capabilities, such as syntax or semantics. UML has the following mechanisms to provide extensibility:

  • stereotype, represent new elements;
  • tagged values, represent new attriutes;
  • constraints, represent boundaries.

They are used to enhance the power of the language. Basically, it's an additional element used to represent some extra behaviour of the system. These extra behaviours are not covered by the standard available notations.

UML - Standard Diagrams

Understanding where and how certain elements are used.

Diagrams and pictures are most efficient to explain complex systems. UML diagrams help to explain a system, but a single diagram is often not enough to describe a whole system.

UML diagrams are usually made in an incremental and iterative way and can be categorized in two main categories:

Structural diagrams

Consists of:

  • Class diagram:
    • Most common element in UML;
    • Classes, interfaces, associations, and collaborations;
    • Static of nature;
    • Represents an object-oriented view of the system.
  • Object diagram:
    • Instance of a class diagram;
    • A set of objects like class diagrams;
    • Used to build prototypes of a system from a practical perspective.
  • Component diagram:
    • Set of nodes and their relationships;
    • Consists of classes, interfaces, or collaborations.
    • Used to visualize implementation.
  • Deployment diagram:
    • Visualizes the deployment of a system;
    • Generally used by deployment teams.

The above described diagrams have common relationships with each other. Component diagrams depend on classes, interfaces, etc. which are part of class/object diagram. Again, the deployment diagram is dependent on the components, which are used to make component diagrams.

Behavioral diagrams

Consists of:

  • Use case diagram:
    • Use cases, actors, and their relationships;
    • Represents a particular functionality of a system;
    • Used to describe functionality and internal/external controllers;
    • These controllers are known as actors.
  • Sequence diagram:
    • An interaction diagram;
    • Sequence of messages flowing from one object to another;
    • Essential from the implementation and execution perspective;
    • Visualizes the sequence of calls in a system to perform functions.
  • Collaboration diagram:
    • Another form of interaction diagram;
    • Represents structural organization of a system and the messages sent/received;
    • Consists of objects and links;
    • Visualizes the organization of objects and their interactions.
  • Statechart diagram:
    • Internal/external events responsible for state change of the system;
    • represents the event driven state change of a system, classes, interface, etc.
  • Activity diagram:
    • Describes the flow of control in a system;
    • Consists of activities and links.
    • Can be sequential, concurrent or branched;
    • They are the functions of a system;
    • Used to visualize the flow of controls in a system and give an idea of the system execution.

UML - Class Diagram

Class diagram is a static diagram reptresenting the static view of an application. They help visualize, describe, and document different aspects of a system, but also help with constructing executable code.

Also known as structural diagrams, they show a collection of classes, interfaces, associations, collaborations, and constraints.

Purpose of class diagrams

  • Analyze and design the static view of an application;
  • Describes the responsibilities of a system;
  • Base for components and deployment diagrams;
  • Forward and reverse engineering.

Drawing a class diagram

  • The name of the class diagram should be meaningful to describe the aspect of the system;
  • Each element and their relationship should be identified in advanced;
  • Responsibilities (attributes & methods) of each class should be clearly identified;
  • Each class should have properties, but avoid bloating by unneccesary additions;
  • Use annotation where needed;
  • Create drafts.

The above diagram is an example of an order system of an application, describing a section of the application.

In the order system diagram...

  • Order and Customer are the system's elements with a one-to-many relationship, because a customer can have multiple orders;
  • The Order class is an abstract class, with two inheriting concrete classes, SpecialOrder and NormalOrder;
  • As inheriting classes, SpecialOrder and NormalOrder share the same properties and methods as Order but with their individual mutations.

Where to use class diagrams

Class diagrams are used for:

  • describing the static view of a system;
  • showing the collaboration between elements of the system;
  • describing the functionalities performed by the system;
  • construction of software applications using object-oriented languages.

UML - Object Diagrams

Object diagrams are derived from and dependent on class diagrams.

They represent an instance of a class diagram, sharing similar concepts.

Like class diagrams, object diagrams share a static view of the system, but at a particular moment of the system operation.

They are used to render a set of objects and their relationships as an instance.

Purpose of object diagrams

  • Forward and reverse engineering;
  • Object relationships in a system;
  • Static view of an interaction;
  • Understanding object behaviour and their releationship from a practical perspective.

Drawing an object diagram

When drawing object diagrams, remember:

  • The object diagram requires a meaningful and intendful name;
  • its most important elements should be identified;
  • the associations between objects should be clarified;
  • values of different elements need to be captured to include the object diagram;
  • proper annotation is important for diagram clarity.

The above example of an object diagram describes the order management system, from the same application used in the class section. It contains the objects:

  • Customer,
  • Order,
  • SpecialOrder,
  • NormalOrder.

The difference in this diagram with the previous class diagram, is that this time it depicts the system interactions of a single customer.

Where to use object diagrams

Object diagrams are most effectively used for:

  • making the prototype of a system;
  • reverse engineering;
  • modeling complex data structures;
  • understanding the system from a practical perspective.

UML - Component Diagrams

Component diagrams help with describing the physical aspects of a system. Physical aspects are elements such as executables, libraries, files, documents, etc. which reside in a node.

They are used to visualize organization and relationships between a system's components and are used to make it executable.

Purpose of component diagrams

Component diagrams:

  • visualize components of a system (libraries, files, executables, documents, etc.);
  • they construct executables by using forward and reverse engineering;
  • describe the organization and relationships of the components.

Drawing a component diagram

When drawing a component diagram, it is essential to identify the following:

  • files used in the system,
  • libraries and other artifacts relevant to the application,
  • relationships between artifacts,
  • a meaningful name,
  • annotation where necessary.

Returning to the previous order system, the diagram above shows the component diagram of the system.

Where to use component diagrams

Component diagrams can be used to:

  • Model the components of a system;
  • Model the database schema;
  • model the executables of an application;
  • model the system's source code.

UML - Deployment Diagrams

Deployment diagrams visualize the topology of the physical components of a system, consisting of nodes and their relationships.

Purpose of a deployment diagram

The main purpose of a deployment diagram are:

  • visualize the hardware topology of a system;
  • describe the hardware components used to deploy software components;
  • describe the runtime processing nodes.

Drawing a deployment diagram

Nodes are the core part of a deployment diagram—they are the physical hardware used to deploy a system.

An efficient deployment diagram controls the following parameters:

  • performance,
  • scalability,
  • maintainability,
  • portability.

Important parts:

  • nodes,
  • relationships among nodes.

The above deployment diagram consists of: monitor, modem, caching server and servers. It shows the nodes of a system and its flow of control throughout.

Where to use deployment diagrams

Deployment diagrams can be used:

  • to model the hardware of a topology system;
  • to model the embedded system;
  • to model the hardware details for a client/server system;
  • to model the hardware details of a distributed application;
  • for forward and reverse engineering.

UML - Use Case Diagrams

Use case diagrams is one type of diagram to describe the dynamic nature of a system. A single use case diagram captures a particular functionality of a system.

Purpose of a use case diagram

Use case diagrams are most commonly used to:

  • gather the requirements of a system;
  • get an outside view of the system;
  • identify the external and internal factors influencing the system;
  • show the interaction amonst the requirements and actors.

Drawing a use case diagram

These are the most important items to consider when drawing a use case diagram:

  • functionalities to be presented as a use case;
  • actors (elements/users that interact with the system);
  • Relationships between the use cases and actors.

Remember:

  • A meaningful name is important;
  • Give actors suitable names;
  • Clearly show relationships and dependancies;
  • Focus on the most essential relationships that most define the system requirement;
  • Annotate where needed.

The above diagram describes the interaction of an outside actor (Customer) with the order management system.

<<Include>> & <<Extend>>

Include- and extend use cases are connected to the base use case.

The include case will happen simultaniously when the base case is called (depicted with a dashed arrow from base to include).

The extend use case will only happen when conditions are met (depicted with a dashed arrow from extend to base).

Specialized use cases

Specialized use cases (children) are cases that inherit their base properties from a general use case (parent), and have their own unique properties.

Specialized use cases are connected to their parent case with a solid line with a outlined arrow.

Where to use a use case diagram

Use case diagrams can be used for:

  • requirement analysis and high level design;
  • model of the context of a system;
  • reverse/forward engineering.

UML - Interaction Diagram

To describe the interactions between elements of a system, there are two types of interaction diagrams: sequence diagram and collaboration diagrams.

Sequence diagrams emphasize on flow of time in a system, while collaboration diagrams focus on the structural organization of the elements of that system.

Purpose of interaction diagrams

The key purpose of interaction diagrams are:

  • to capture the dynamic behaviour of a system;
  • to describe the message flow in the system;
  • to describe the structural organization of the objects;
  • to describe the interaction between objects.

Drawing an interaction diagram

Interactions show snapshots of a running system, capturing an instance of a dynamic system.

The following should be considered when drawing an interaction diagram:

  • objects taking part in the interaction;
  • message flow between objects;
  • the sequence in which the messages are flowing;
  • object organization.

Sequence diagrams

The above diagram, consisting of Customer, Order, SpecialOrder, and NormalOrder shows the sequence of messages. It shows the method calls between objects.

Collaboration diagram

Collaboration diagrams focus more on order and organization of a system, when timing is less important.

Where to use interaction diagrams

Interaction diagrams can be used to:

  • model the flow of control by time sequence;
  • model the flow of control by a structural organization;
  • forward/reverse engineering.

UML - Statechart Diagrams

Statechart diagrams depict the different states that a system can have, which are controlled by internal or external events.

The main purposes of a statechart diagram are:

  • to model the dynamic aspect of a system;
  • to model the lifetime of a reactive system;
  • to describe different sates of an object during its lifetime;
  • to define a state machine to model the states of an object.

Drawing a statemachine diagram

Consider:

  • the identities of important objects to be analyzed;
  • the identity of states;
  • the identity of events.

The above diagram depicts the details of state changes in an Order object.

Where to use statechart diagrams:

Statechart diagrams are commonly used:

  • to model the object states of a system;
  • to model the reactive system, which consist of reactive objects;
  • to identify the events responsible for state changes;
  • forward/reverse engineering.

UML - Activity Diagrams

Like statemachine diagrams, activity diagrams also describe the dynamic aspects of a system. It is a flowchart to represent the flow from one activity to another.

Flow between operations can be sequential, branched, or concurrent; using different elements such as fork, join, etc.

Purpose of activity diagrams

Activity diagrams:

  • draw the activity flow of a system;
  • describe the sequence from one activity to another;
  • describe the parallel, branched and concurrent flow of the system.

Drawing an activity diagram

While creating an activity diagram, focus on:

  • activities,
  • associations,
  • conditions,
  • constraints.

The above diagram of an order management system shows four activities of a system, from order request to dispatch.

Note: activity diagrams cannot exactly match code, thus are mainly used by the business users.

Where to use activity diagrams

Activity diagrams are best used for:

  • modeling workflow by using activities;
  • modeling business requirements;
  • high level understanding of the system's functionalities;
  • investigating business requirements at a later stage.
